reviewText: The story of Nicky Cruz is indeed a powerful one & certainly relevant today. Unfortunately, this movie is so outdated that few high school or college students would be able to sit & watch it without laughing outright.The music is horrible (read HORRIBLE). I'm not even convinced that most of secular society would have appreciated it back when this film was made, though I could be wrong on that point. It all seemed to fit so poorly with the movie's premise, & instead of helping the mood of scenes, it actually took much away from what might have been still impactful today.Most of the fight scenes were poorly choreographed & some were reminiscent of "West Side Story". I half-expected the gangs to break into a song & dance number at any given moment. Along with that, though I understand the director was attempting to avoid a violent bloodbath on film, this movie could not possibly have accurately depicted ganglife. Most teens & young adults see worse in their own schools. To be fair, I was impressed with Pat Boone's ability to portray a non-judgemental Christian, though there were a few times when the camera angles portrayed him as almost angelic. (David Wilkerson is certainly someone to respect, but let's be realistic.) I am not a fan of Boone, but he handled his role decently enough. It was also pretty neat to see Erik Estrada when he was so young.I'm sorry to say that I regret having purchased this movie. Not b/c the story is bad or even due to a poor script, but simply b/c it is not something I could ever share with the students in my youth group & their friends who would benefit from Cruz's story. Due to my husband's & my own struggle to see beyond the poor quality & dated nature of this film, I have little faith that our students would be able to get much from it.This movie has impacted many, I realize. The story of Nicky Cruz is important, & people today should be exposed to it. Unfortunately, this film won't cut it in secular society today or even in many Christian ones. I hope that one of these days someone will remake this movie in a more realistic way with modern technology, pertinent music, & improved acting. Until then, I'll be referring them to the book & to Cruz's book "Run, Baby, Run".
summary: Bad Music & Acting Kill This Movie

reviewerName: Bartok Kinski "A casual stroll through the lu...
reviewText: I guess I'll be the first one to go against the grain here but I am a secular critic and this Evangelical Christian movie is not only uninteresting, but beyond silly.I didn't cry with the same rigorous intensity as the rest of the movie theater. I didn't cry at all. Yeah, no kidding. Ask the rest of the movie theater. What an overated bore. I am still feeling all dead.The major issue with it, is that it was so cliched. Go see it. I will not tell you it was well acted because if I hated it so much it obviously wasn't.I have never laughed so hard and cried so little (at all) - all at the same time- for any movie. I usually laugh behind my hand so as not to disturb others but during this movie, I felt liberated to be silent as hard, loud and as long as I wanted.I won't tell you casting was perfect because if I hated the characters and don't miss them already, it obviously wasn't.It was never sly or delicate at the same time. It was not poetic - a description of life that reminds you of your life- your day- today is my day. We are alive, no? It reminds you of that in death.Layers and layers of cliched words, thoughts, situations...you just want to dive in and never come up to the surface again.There's a pretty interesting approach to these dumb religious films, an approach of cultic religion and of people using it as a veneer to hide serious structural defects in their souls and lives, and what happens when that facade starts to crack and fall off.
summary: The Cross and the Dollar Sign

reviewText: The acting may be a bit on the poor side, but this is an awesome and powerful movie.  This movie is about a small town minister in a gang-infested city, trying to get the word of God across to the gangs.  Trying to get Gods unconditional love across to the gangs.  He wants to fill the gangs with love so bad, that he does whatever it takes, including entering their "turf" to tell them that Jesus loves them.  I'm telling you, this movie is just powerful to see who and what God's love can change.  I highly recommend this movie to all, Christian or not.  Even though the acting is a bit so-so, I am giving it all 5 stars because of the power I believe this movie has.  Please watch this movie.  You will be moved.God Bless!

summary: An old film with an ever lasting message

reviewText: In tribute to the film; it was an early attempt at a Christian movie dealing with drugs and violence.  I also sympathize with the fact that a film has only so much time to delve into a story that a book has pages and pages to get across.  That said, the movie deviated so far from the actual account given in the book that the story itself was almost unrecognizable.  There were only a few parts where the filmmakers seemed to do some level of justice to an occurrence in the book, and these were often poorly done.For instance: in the book the two major gangs which Wilkerson interacted with WERE the Mau Maus and the Bishops, however, the two gangs had an alliance and were waging war on the police.  In the movie, though, these two gangs were at war.  I understand that the filmmakers were attempting to show the devastation of gang violence, but I think that there were better ways of doing it than completely ignoring the real story.Also, I think it would have been better to have made the film a period piece.  I believe they tried to 'modernize' it (the film came out in 1970), probably so that it would be more relatable to a 1970's audience.  However, Wilkerson's early interactions with the gangs actually took place in the late 50's, early 60's closer to the period of West Side Story; thus some of the slang was changed, and adding certain 'hippie' styles I think really detracted.  The 70's music was also distracting from some of the 'intense' things potentially going on in the film.The overall message was ambiguous, and any real doctrine was lost.  I understand that, particularly in the early 70's (and even today) it would be much tougher to get funding for a Christian film that was 'Pentecostal,' in message (which the book was), but when all is said and done there was left no strong message at all.The casting was good, and I also liked the way that the city 'felt' in the film (sort of), but again it wholly lacked the impact of the book (which is not surprising since the events of the book were changed so drastically).

reviewText: The Cross And The Switchblade is the special anniversary edition DVD, which was digitally restored from the original 35mm negative. This is the now classic story of how the life-changing message of Jesus Christ gave a gang leader the inspiration and opportunity to transform his violent life into something better. Reaching out to the hopes and fears of young folks everywhere, The Cross And The Switchblade is dramatic, vivid, and very highly recommended viewing. This 105 minutes, fully color DVD production is enhanced with extra features including 8 language tracks, English sub-titles, commentary by writer/director Don Murray and associate producer Dr. A. Kenneth Curtis, actor biographies, and more.
summary: Dramatic, vivid, and very highly recommended viewing

reviewText: This movie is excellent, and very moving, a must see for the whole family. The subject matter is still very relevent today. Erik Estrada is outstanding in his role, as is Pat Boone. Covering the subject of gangs and religion is not easy to do well, but this movie manages to do it.

reviewText: I usually stay away from religious films because they don't have the money to match the production values of commercial films.  Often a really good message is spoiled by a poor script and below standard acting.  However, I read the book, The Cross and the Switchblade back in the 60's and it was so inspiring that I've never forgotten it.  I actually went to the area where the action took place a couple of years later when I moved to New York, intending to join the Teen Challenge movement.  I spent a whole day looking for the place, and only learned, a few years later that they had moved to Brooklyn.So, when I saw this on Netflix, I signed up for it.  Again, I didn't expect a lot.  I was never a Pat Boone fan.  So I was very pleasantly surprised at the film.  It's the power of the story that carries you over the sometimes amateurish production.  It was a true story and nothing can change that.  I also found Pat Boone to be very good in the role.  He didn't overact and after a few minutes I forgot who he was and saw him totally as David Wilkerson.  (In the bios, it mentioned that he graduated cum laude from Columbia...who knew?  He got a bad rap from Hollywood, which has never been kind to professing Christians.  I admire him for refusing to sell out for success. )A young Eric Estrada was great as Nicky Cruz and the whole cast seemed to be swept up in the spirit of the film.  It wasn't as moving as the book, but not very many films are.There were some interesting features, most notably a filmed sermon by Nicky Cruz in South Africa.  He is really an impressive person.Non Christians probably won't go for the film (see the one star review) but others, who connect to the central story, should be able to overcome the fact that it is dated, and low budget, and find it an inspiring experience.
summary: Low Budget film with a Great Message

reviewText: The acting was great.  I don't remember Pat Boone being such a good actor, but he was terrific in this as was Eric Estrada and everyone really.  The scenery was so realistic and helped to convey the desperation of the gang members' and junkies' lives.  It is hard to put a great book on film and capture it's essence, especially for a true story.  I think this one did a fantastic job.  Riveting throughout.Having been curious to read the book again,a fter seeing the movie, I hasten to add that a lot was left out.  The basic idea is intact, and, again, they did a great job in the short time a movie takes.  But if you want to learn more and be even more blessed, ya gotta read the book.

reviewText: This film is so powerful - prepare to be deeply moved! Real life account of David Wilkerson, preacher to the gangs who meets up with Nicky Cruz - warlord of one of the worst gangs who terrorized the streets of New York.You can tell it was filmed on a low budget, but this doesn't detract from the film.Emotions of characters range from fear, guilt, anger, bitterness, hate, rage to forgiveness & a love that overcomes it all.Special features include a look at David Wilkerson's work today on the streets, featuring some of the projects that have been set up.A film that will inspire & challenge!Billy Graham Presents: The Climb
Title: N/A

reviewText: Both Pat Boone (Debbie's dad and known for his infamous No More Mr. Nice Guy CD) and especially Erik Estrada do a fine job acting in this one!  The  music is a little dated, but that's not the point of the movie.  The  highlight is seeing the respectable preacher turn around the hearts of many  hardened gang members.  It has its funny scenes as well, like the girl  singing the song and the gang members taunt her.  Most of all, it's an  inspiring movie based on a true story.  The Lord works in mysterious ways  and anybody's life can change for the better!
